utterances: Now, the deal was that the city of Charlotte would repeal its gay rights protection measure, and then the state would repeal HB2, the so-called bathroom bill.
Charlotte says it upheld its end of the bargain passing a repeal and then another.
Why do you think the legislature failed to keep its part of the deal?
What happened is that the Republican caucuses buckled on the Republican leaders.

And the frustrating thing is that if they had simply put the legislation out on the floor for a vote, it would have passed with the requisite Democrats and Republicans who were for this voting together.
But we know that this is costing us, and we've got to fix it.
As you mentioned, there's real economic harm from this bill.
There have been boycotts.
Big companies have decided not to expand in North Carolina.
As long as this law is in place, how do you plan to address the ongoing economic harm that it's doing to the state's economy?
First, I'm telling businesses that this governor's election was the first step.
So...
But they weren't boycotting the governor.
They were boycotting the state because of House Bill 2, which is still in effect.
The governor was the start of House bill 2.
I'm going to argue to businesses and others that you still need to come to North Carolina.
You need to expand.
You need to bring your sporting events and entertainment events here.
But when you come, help me repeal House Bill 2.
Help me make sure that our laws reflect North Carolinians and who we really are.
I want to ask more broadly about your ability to work with the legislature.
Last week of course Republicans passed this sweeping measure to curb your power.
It made your cabinet subject to legislative approval.
It cut your political appointees from the 1,500 that your predecessor had down to 425 people, lots of other changes that advantage Republicans.
You've said that you'll challenge this in court, but how are you going to govern with a legislature that is so determined to put up roadblocks in your way?
First, I'm going to make sure that I continue to work with them in areas where we can work together.
For example, as we were fighting about these issues, at the same time, we were negotiating on House Bill 2.
I think...
I'm sorry, but if House Bill 2 is your example of where you can work together, last night seems to indicate...
Well...
...The contrary.
But, Ari, they agreed with me.
They ended up having a revolt in their caucus.
But the point of the matter is - is that we were talking about this, and we were working on an agreement even with the storm of the other issues.
I believe that there are Republicans in the legislature who do want to raise our teacher pay to at least the national average.
They want to work with me on bringing good jobs to North Carolina.
I'm going to be...
I don't want to sound rude, but isn't that a little naive in light of what the legislature...
No.
...Has been doing for the last two weeks?
I love discovering new places.
Last year, I drove all around Africa, I crossed deserts, climbed mountains, run marathons, bungee jump, mountain bike, scuba dive and snorkel everywhere because I'm practically a fish myself.
As for trying new things, how about riding an ostrich?
What can I say?
Animals love me, and I love them, too, especially if they're rare.
Okay, maybe no that rare.
I'm a great communicator, love meeting people and immersing myself in other cultures.

I've written newspaper and magazine articles, given TV and radio interviews, and kept the journal and video blog on my Web site to share my experiences with others, and I'd love to do the same to you.
We can learn about 100 miles of magic, Great Barrier Reef together and all the Queensland has to offer.
I'm experienced (unintelligible) manager, charity fundraiser and tour guide.
I have a Bachelor of Science degree and a keen interest in photography.
So I'm your man.
Well, that may be his dream job, but what is yours?
Call and tell us what your best job in the world is, 800-989-8255.
Email: talk@npr.org.
You could also join the conversation on our Web site.
Go to npr.org.
Click on TALK OF THE NATION.
Chris O'Toole joins us now from London, where he's editor of the travel Web site, Travelbite.co.uk.
And he's been following the Best Job in the World contest since it's started last January.
Chris, nice to have you on TALK OF THE NATION today.
Mr.
CHRIS O'TOOLE (Editor, Travelbite.co.uk): Good.
Hey, Neal.
How you doing?
I'm well, thanks.

Now, this was quite a publicity coup, on the part of the Queensland Tourism office in Australia who thought of this contest, not only got a ton of publicity, they've also made quite a bit of money, and they've got themselves a caretaker?
Mr.
O'TOOLE: Yeah.
This is the second time this has come around.
And about three months ago, they put the advertisement out, originally, and now they've selected the winner (unintelligible) become a (unintelligible) news story around the world again.
And they've promoted this job magnificently and, well, I guess it's a pretty good job.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Mr.
O'TOOLE: It is.
It's an amazing job on an island, Hamilton Island, which is one of the larger islands in the Great Barrier Reef.
But obviously, you get the accommodation, but you also got quite a fantastic paycheck as well.
And amidst all of this competition, 34,000 applicants, do you know how they decided who wins?
Mr.
O'TOOLE: I think the Queensland Tourism people narrowed it down from 34,000 original applicants.
Ten thousand of which were from America.
They create the shortlist of 50 people, which the public then voted for.
The top 16 were then selected, flown out to Australia, and they chose the winner today.
And so, he now has to get - you know, it's horrible to think about it, but he has to actually do this job now.
Mr.
O'TOOLE: Yeah.
He's allowed to take one person with him, his friend I guess.
But now, he's going to have a pretty much the time of his life, I think - weekly blog updates, photography, things like that.
I think it's going to be an ongoing advertisement for the next six months.
And obviously, then, the tourist board can do it again.
Mr.
O'TOOLE: Yeah, they'll probably repeat it next year.
I'll be surprised if other countries don't try a very similar thing.
I do have to ask, Chris, did you apply?
Mr. O'TOOLE: No. I don't have the technical proficiency on the - on a camera unfortunately.
But I obviously would've liked to be involved.
Did you get down to Australia to take a look at the digs?
Mr. O'TOOLE: I haven't been on there personally.
I think there's a quite a lot of British journalists out there at the moment.
But I personally haven't been there.
And interesting, might things have been a little rigged for Briton to win this contest?
Mr.

O'TOOLE: I wouldn't like to say, but I'd be surprised if - Britain's obviously a very big market for the Australian tourist industry, so I think it's - it may have had some role in their selection of British tourists.
Because there's a lot of Brits who go down to Australia and, well, the publicity probably didn't hurt.
Mr.
O'TOOLE: With obviously the strong cultural language ties we have with Australia, a lot of the history, I think that may have played a role.
There were 3,000 applications from the U.K.
and over 11,000 from America, so who's to say.
Well, Chris O'Toole, thanks very much for your time today.
We appreciate it.
Mr. O'TOOLE: Thank you.
Chris O'Toole is editor of the travel Web site, Travelbite.co.uk.
And he joined us today from the studios of the BBC in London.
Anyway, we'd like to hear what your dream job is - that one in Australia has now been filled - 800-989-8255.
Email is talk@npr.org.
Jessica's calling us from Salem, Massachusetts.
